messages.content: Open v0.1 questions that would be great for folks to think about while Im out grocery shopping:
Role of general members in 0.1
Review and approval process
Multisig governance
For the multisig I think @sabina had ideas already.
As for the LLC, Wyoming did recently pass a law that allows you to incorporate a DAO as an LLC + codify the smart contracts as law: https://sos.wyo.gov/Business/Docs/DAOs_FAQs.pdf

V1.0 on the DAO side, a carry structure involving the token generated by projects may be worth looking into. In this way everyone in the DAO has incentive to contribute to due diligence in the projects applying for funding.

Morning folks. Will take some of the updates from the various channels into the notion docs today.
Would ask though that it doesnt become too centralised, the docs are open edit so anyone can add suggestions or proposals or tweaks!
On the WY DAO LLC, a few folks have looked into it and while its nice marketing its pretty untested and the syndicate/UA+LLC model is likely a safer bet right now.
@JayIRL do you want to keep the hyperscalegov notion separate from the general-info notion?

Not tied to it no, just started it before the other one was started.
Just as long as I have a contact to ask for additional pages (Assuming we are not adding everyone as team members)
I'll add you; pm for email
@JayIRL for liquidity provider. What if as a member of DAO, we can also contribute like DAO's grant?
And for DAO's tech & voting when can start with aragon.org
Plan for future is definitely to have community members not just be contributors but the main source of LP funding.
Ah excellent yes these kind of things are exactly tooling we need, any other similar toolsets out there we should look at?
The Notion doc mentions technical governance - can you wrap more of a definition on that?
Yes. Let me make a list and we can choose based on our need.

Yeah I want to have a logical split between

Technical Governance - aspects that interact directly with onchain assets.
Process Governance - aspects that are more focused on the application/selection/investment flows 

Process governance actions will trigger events that are handled under technical governance if that makes sense (Im still drinking my first morning coffee so it may not!)
Links above updates, docs now moved across to the main Hyperscale Notion

https://hyperscale.notion.site/Tooling-Options-278911278c1b471787625d4ea2e2701a if you can throw anything you find/know about into there that would be great, we can use that page as our scratchpad for tooling

embeds.title: Tooling Options
embeds.description: A new tool for teams & individuals that blends everyday work apps into one.

messages.content:
@JayIRL Interesting! I've found that both of the governance processes tend to intertwine. Example from above - applications are selected by vote, right? Are those votes handled on-chain? Who designs the voting system?

I guess my question is - how do you think they'd be separable?

Speed and the fact that the ofchain to onchain move will take time.
We also have the additional overhead of the legal and regulatory perspectives so some things may need to be offchain until v1.0 comes about and we move to a full onchain ecyosystem around the DAO and the Fund.
For example, with the applications, filter stage with SME review may be off chain now until we build that platform, but will move onchain in future.
And its us here in this channel we have that task of designing the voting systems, allocation mechanisms etc.
Awesome - I'm in one of the right spots then. I get the v0.1 part, certainly - we've just marched through hell RE: legal/regulatory work at my company.
Same here, more fun to do the work here tho, without corporate overhead and slowness 🙂
Got it.
@JayIRL and others: check the Trail to see if there are major governance developments not listed https://www.notion.so/hyperscale/d6ade7e7b8234755a496bf9d1e926398?v=0d6773235422491d9b55a0b94a467e41

embeds.title: The Trail
embeds.description:
A feed of substantive changes in the flow. Summarized periodically into The Guide.
 → Click

messages.content:
Big ones are there yup, have started build out of details on notion under the governance section today.
Dont think any of those raise to the level of major events though
hey

So for tooling Im 100% in the blind. We need platforms to help with governance proposals, voting, reviews etc. and Im out of my dept on that. 
Notion page for that is https://hyperscale.notion.site/Tooling-Options-278911278c1b471787625d4ea2e2701a

messages.content:
And on voting its more about what is best practise, what can we learn from other DAOs on their challenges, what has worked what hasnt, what can we cut and paste in to learn from the ones that have come before.
Notion page for long term on that would be https://hyperscale.notion.site/v1-0-The-Long-Term-2d4b78b8b00e4ae0925372abea018879

messages.content: ok. I'll take a look tonight. Anything else I should know?

No big thing is if you feel passionate about any aspect just take it and run, my main goal is just to be coordinator and distiller, Im still learning as i go also so there is no owership of anything yet, I just shout the loudest sometimes and end up with things!
ok perfect!
And Ive just had a 18hr day so Im going to go pass out now 🙂

I haven’t looked through notion yet (so sorry if this has already been proposed) but I’ve seen Snapshot.org being used to poll dao members. Im not super familiar with voting mechanisms but thought I’d chime in with that!
Additionally, and this may be more on the operational side, I’ve seen Coordinape being used
Drop them into the Notion Tooling options above - we'll have to hold a comparison at some point.

RE: Tooling - one of the open questions that we'll have to address is the type of consensus mechanism we're using. I guess there's a #legacy-voting channel now, but that speaks directly to the tooling choices. Ex: Aragon is optimistic - proposals pass automatically unless challenged. Is this what we want?
Right we need to defien our requirments and then need to chosse a tool which fullfill it. Let's collabe we all and get it done.
As @JayIRL said (https://discord.com/channels/916751469678579784/917002777304105000/917706621772234813) that for V0.1 we can go with ofchanin and I like that idea.

We should really think about what the main offer is and we should focus governance on that.

Easy to get distracted by funding, but it’s likely that community support and gaining publicity are going to be a bigger drawing power than small level funding. Funding is the spark that ignites everything but it’s facilitating the day to day experience of early stage that we should probably focus on.

Maybe building in some level of community ownership once we figure out how to do that to encourage networked collaborate/ support. So that everyone has skin in every game.

Initially governance should focus on building / protecting a web3 community. It might be worth drawing up some key guiding principles for that.
Kevalin noted that the community piece is next, first we need to focus on being able to make investments.
I show it and Mirror's fund rasing is a good option.
I studied some of the existing DAOS in Investment/Funding and most of the existing DAO stakes are from: Aragon, daohaus.club, juicebox.

Key requires are:
1. Fundraising 
2. Fund/Treasury management
3. Voting 

Top reliable Tools:
1. Mirror.xyz 
2. juicebox.money
3. snapshot.org
4. gnosis.io
5. daohaus.club
6. aragon.org
This is great @mhrnik could you throw that into https://www.notion.so/hyperscale/Tooling-Options-278911278c1b471787625d4ea2e2701a also so we get it all in once place.

embeds.title: Tooling Options

messages.content: Wouldn’t we make it easier (governance) for v1 to keep members to 99 - as it reduces legal scrutiny and fees to get the right legal stack.
Yeah that was one of the thoughts, if we formalise the DAO side in v0.1 we go <99 formal members to stay inside the investment club rules

Challenge is that it can feel excusionary and we dont have a delegation program yet, we might end up with 1000 members but no fast mechanism, as we dont have a token, to do delegation to get to the 99 goal
Good for v.01 for sure. Also helps with figuring out scale in comms, voting, etc - as they get messy if we can’t have the right  feedback loops.
You could do v1 99 - V2 9999 v3 99999 - until you get to Nx?

Thats why for some of this I want to wait until Core team move onto Community focus, then we will get a good idea of the box that we need to design for from a governance processes and tooling perspective
As I can see you will be able to group members by their strengths and believability in certain areas. Which helps with believability weighted voting to increase likelihood of the best ideas to win.
Personally thats my hope.
Same page
Let me know how I can help. Have some experience building believability weighted tooling like is know at e.g. bridge water

ON day 1 we spoke about a beleivability measure and token for those who review and do DD on applications, so that would be awesome. Hasnt really been talking about since that first night but I hope its still on the cards.

You’ll need some baseline and progress KPI/milestone to create feedback loop to understand which votes weight more. E.g. Idea X gets picked by Anon A and idea Y by Anon B. Would e.g. speed to ship, dev traction (GitHub contributions), and other inputs such as growth and engagement in Discord help for initial traction feedback loop so at the next vote, the Anon who voted for the current idea ahead on these metrics would weigh more.
有中文吗？

Are you referring to votes on investments or general votes? They might need to have different weighting strategies. A vote from an active developer could probably weigh less on an investment decision than from someone that has a good investment-voting record.
Yes. I think I should add pricing as well that how much, each tool cost.

Treasury management is going to be critical.  Most DAOs seem to use volatile Layer 1 crypto and protocol tokens to manage their treasury.  Think that's a mistake.  I'd keep a treasury mainly in stablecoins.  Stake some stabelcoins in DeFi protocols if you want yield.  Tried to explain this in more detail here: https://davefriedman.substack.com/p/daos-have-a-treasury-management-problem .  Happy to discuss in more detail if anyone is interested.

embeds.title: DAOs Have a Treasury Management Problem
embeds.description: Buy the rumor, sell the news

messages.content: Sure. You can share your more thought and also help me add tools that can help to reduce the risk. https://www.notion.so/Tooling-Options-278911278c1b471787625d4ea2e2701a

embeds.title: Tooling Options

messages.content: Will take a look at this soon and provide some feedback.
Here is an even more comprehensive representation
Thanks. Right now we're looking for DAO's stacks that fit the project's framework.
that color scheme is breaking my 🧠
Blame cooper turley 🤣

OK I took a quick look at the Treasury Management tools you mention in your graphic.  I'm unclear what features they offer.  Basically, a DAO treasury should hold most of its treasury in stablecoins.  If the DAO wants yield then stake some of the stablecoin with a DeFi protocol and customize a fixed rate yield with something like Element Finance.  If these Treasury Management tools can do that--then great.  I'm pretty sure that Element Finance is working with Gnosis (maybe?) on this kind of integration.  Hopefully that helps.
Agree. It's a good idea to have/hold fun in a stable coin to avoid unwanted Volatility. Let's see how the community decides the funding process.

For contribution:
1. Pick the role first.
2. Start with: https://hyperscale.notion.site/Governance-9a9fa9b1b56e4abbb1e1e0d72d324834
3. As @kevalin announced, In governance, one of the  main goals is:
- Simplify & standardize DAO creation (considering one-click DAOs)
So if you want to start with it, Refer & Contribute here: https://hyperscale.notion.site/Tooling-Options-278911278c1b471787625d4ea2e2701a
@JayIRL can we pin this last message so it can help to know what's going on with this channel?

Yes @jzlegion can you help us out there, pin the final message just above here and also the very first message in this channel here https://discord.com/channels/916751469678579784/917002777304105000/917003951663108117

Yeah for sure! In essence you need to build up the track record and get some KPIs established for early signals, vs lagging indicators. Could wel be you are right in the short term, wrong in the longterm. But as the focus is on deploying capital fast you need early signals.

And baselines perhaps, but they easily become biased or pushed toward historical authority, which then becomes a self fulfilling prophecy. The strength can be the Anons votes and reasoning show the quality of the decision not pure status like e.g. Sam Altman votes +1 then you get herd mentality. You want meritocratic weighted voting.
This is interesting - we've been talking about this RE: AI work. The voting shouldn't be reductive and the data system should allow us to tease out some causality from  indicators.

Namely, a strict yes/no vote without context/analysis isn't as useful as it could be.
But @LZRS and I are on the same page with you that metrics on the analysts is the right call.
Hello James, QQ how is the delegation program going to work? I want to be part of those 99
Can some of the @mod  please ban the spam accounts?
@kevalin also spam here ^
Done
do we have a way to connect ?
Can you share what are you looking for? Maybe I can help.

Ok folks, we are back live again.
So I have a challenge for the team, we need a proposal and voting process in place ASAP fro DAO decisions (Not related to the race voting), needs to be light, fast and implementatable with minimal friction.

I think we can have 2 categories of proposals, minor and major.
Minor I suggest we have a channel on discord and have a basic up/down structure. Not sure if we need to go as far as a bot but maybe @jzlegion you could chime in here on ideas?
Major I suggest we get a basic snapshot setup, pre-token. @xinyi you said you might be able to help us with this?

For how to split between the two categories Ill write up a proposal today and lets see where we go from here.

Firstly I propose we petition an FOI to see how many active hidden channels there are.

I see a lot of roles that can only be acquired if you are anointed by a mod. No process or description of what these roles are.
Why would a DAO have tiered roles?

How can you discuss governance in good faith, when you aren’t even sure you have full visibility of the org?

Shouldn’t this discussion be reserved for higher up the hierarchy? e.g. at the core team level, or even higher up at the mod level, or even higher up again at the sama batphone level, or at god level with sama offline? (yes I know this is supposed to be a DAO).
@Inklin I agree with you ?
https://hyperscalefund.notion.site/Structure-8b25c68113694dd999d7e5f7aa704bad

embeds.title: Structure
embeds.description: The Hyperscale ecosystem consists of two primitives: core teams & bounty markets. Core teams focus on long-term goals while bounty participants focus on short-term goals.

messages.content: We're starting off quite centralized
As we scale we'll become more decentralized
Being centralized & hierarchical allows us to move fast
Decentralized orgs are frozen
Thanks for this, this is very important news, so the big point is that for the moment at least then this is not a DAO?
It's an early stage DAO
All DAOs start this way
Sushi
Ethereum
Bitcoin
Any decentralized org
Ethereum and Bitcoin are frozen
But started centralized and moved fast
Not here to argue, just want to make sure that we are on the same page, as this is a big change from the initial vision of 2 weeks ago.
Current vision: Centralised Org that will build the v0.1 to eventually move into a DAO operating model.
It's more nuanced. We use the Orca pod structure. You have the right idea.
https://orca.mirror.xyz/Y2xvPmB4cJH51srGqY6Mm_g38lV-7cwvtyDePnyzfAE

embeds.title: Pods: The DAOnfall of Token Voting — Mirror
embeds.description: Written by: Maria Gomez (@MyPaoG), Julia Rosenberg (@JulzRoze), and Chun Poon (@zkchun)

messages.content: @kevalin Do we need a voting tool for governance?
web2 solution can also work for now, right?
Vote with browser wallets
That's the plan
And those wallets are connected to this server
Through web3.hyperscalefund.com
Not now but soon
Got you.

Thanks for sharing this, not a huge amount out there about hw it works due to it still being in private beta.
But seems like they essentially help manage full governance stack, so this channel wont likely be needed as we are using off the shelf process.
TBH thats very dissapointing for me personally as we had put a lot of work in over the past 2 weeks to begin iteration on what governance could look like but at the end of the day if Core wants to go this way then thats that.
I will stick around to offer advice but will likely not contribute much until we get beyond the more traditional model, not a huge amount of space for innovation in governance structures there (Which will get PMF faster sure, but less interesting for me personally)
If folks want me to weigh in on anything please always feel free to ping or DM!

Two things
1. DAOs that we invest in will need help figuring out governance. They're the sandbox
2. We'll use tools in the tool stack

Also we're probably not going to use Orca. What we're looking at is the high level idea

Ok I accept that, but I hope you see where the frustrations are coming from, we had a group here working on governance, and then out of nowhere without even a note to the contributors here our work was deleted, the channel closed and a governance structure decided upon by the core team somewhere else. Thats not what I was here for personally, if Im just building what others are deciding in a closed group then theres nothing new here to have fun with. I think that that will work for some folks, but for me thats not the attractive part of contributing to DAOs.

As you said maybe the best place for me personally might be in helping out some of the DAOs that we invest in that have some interesting challenges!

Yeah I see what you mean. Just changed the sub-domain. It's still up.

V0.1 (The Short Term) Governance Doc: https://oldhyperscale.notion.site/v0-1-The-Short-Term-3753d29ba764476cb1c628393a8a59a4

H

messages.content: Ok that makes me feel a little better at least thanks!!!

@kevalin thanks for the reply, I really appreciate it. 
Again, I want to stress I’m not trying to be confrontational, just being very candid.

In the beginning (day 1) we had an adhocracy, and the cry was speed, speed, speed. 
So naturally people poured in and charged off in random directions and chatted in small groups.

But by day 2 or 3 the adhocracy was crystallised into a hierarchy with tiered roles “core” and “none core”, this didn’t happen organically or bottom up, it was at the behest of the mods. These two tiers then moved at different speeds and with different levels of engagement. 

Fast forward 2 weeks and the tiers are miles apart, almost talking a different language, non-core people have no idea what is happening because the core teams are opaque.
I’m not even complaining about this, it’s impressive to have built something. But as a DAO experiment, did we really even learn anything? I would argue not.
Yes the core teams built an investment MVP very fast, but why even open a discord server and invite 100’s of people from public into a DAO community if you’re going to do all the work with a tiny core group at the direction of a single person?

This discord feels like a holding tank. We all sit here like mushrooms whilst the core teams build the MVP and make all of the decisions.
Again, not complaining progress seems to have been fast, but why not say all this up front? This isn’t what was advertised in public.

In my experience new communities go through forming>storming>norming>performing to get to the place the magic happens. 
Here we tossed aside the community development whilst it was still only just forming and in the name of speed and just transplanted in a core team that was already performing.

Isn’t there a danger that it feels like the DAO aspect is just a marketing wrapper for offline capital and devs?
If you could decide what Hyperscale and the community does next what would you do?
@evann what are your thoughts on this?

imo, DAOs should be small, and interop with each other. 

I'm not sure yet how to do that in Hyperscale.

I think the problem with Hyperscale is that there's no clear direction. A ton of people in a server. Infinite possibilities: DAO tooling, investing marketplace, etc.

Need to set a direction that people can follow. Be clear and post updates.
There's no community alignment or reason for being here
It's very inorganic
That's what I'm trying to figure out
Why does Hyperscale exist, what are we trying to do, what are we working towards?
Hmmmm maybe just ask the community. We have so many people here. What would you do with Hyperscale? Then choose whatever the community aligns around do. Post updates & be transparent.
Could make this announcement
tbh, I think if:
The idea is that Hyperscale is the umbrella under which this all happens

- there's a clear way for folks to contribute as funders
- there's a clear way for folks to support portfolio 

Then you're kind of fine
Also give everyone a token for voting

The simplest thing that we can do right now is post a clear roadmap. Have the community vote an aspects of it & make suggestions. Then have a very transparent core team that frequently communicates with the community.

So this is the challenge and I see why its a struggle (and I comiserate with you on that!!)
I think that we started off as a value add investment fund, we seem to have morphed into some umbrella DAO that builds an entire ecosystem, thats an NP hard problem and requires insane amounts of work and effort.
If we went back to the fundamentals that came from Samas tweet (What is it: For v0.1 Its an investment fund with a DAO as the decisionmakers) then we vastly reduce the complexity.
Then once we have that in place, and we make investment 1 etc. Then we have time to work towards v1.0, which can have all of the long term issues, one click DAO, support processes ecosystem development etc.
We cant solve for 100 before we have gotten from 0 to 1 imo

100% that would be a huge step forward alone, then folks can say yup this is what Im here for, or others may decide not to. but at least then its community driven and you have something to actually build structure around
I wonder if it makes sense to keep channels open (and readable) but only write-able by pod members. I wonder if this affects speed in anyway 🤔
That's a good idea

Yup I would like to see more structure with the roles and channels etc, its defo a mess at the moment.
Governance folks should be willing to work and build on governance, legal on legal topics etc. other wise there gets a lot of "my 2c" stuff.

Then have the big picture stategy stuff get defined by Core - "Ok next 2 weeks we are working on X" and each of the groups then goes and says. ok what do we need to do to contribute to this, and start building and delivering back outcomes.
Agree with this as well. Transparency and a clear roadmap are big. I've felt myself getting a little turned off be the lack of these, and I've seen others expressing the same feelings as well.

I don't think there's a problem having Hyperscale divided into Core and Community, but agree with James here that big picture strategy and decisionmaking should be defined publicly. Otherwise those in the community think they're helping but are really working on last weeks objective that got thrown out

Transparency around how Core works would be helpful as well. Not sure how people get added to Core. I've seen James doing excellent work and being extremely involved almost since the beginning, but he's not on Core. I've seen others with the Core tag who have not seemed that active (at least in Discord), and it's unclear how the were chosen, and by whom
instead of roadmap clear and open-sourced timeline?
(Just for the record to make it very clear this for me personally is not about being on Core or not, am only thinking from the big picture success factors here)
Same here. I love what we've built and the momentum we have and I want to see it succeed. This isn't about personal status
agree

Strong decentralization requires a strong culture and a clear vision. In  order to work in scrappy teams, everyone has to be aligned and transparent, which requires a degree of centralization aka documentation. I’ve seen how decentralized work, works, from remote first companies and Amazon. Good guard rails and foundations that allow for agile work are important

I'll echo everyone here - setting a high level vision that we all can agree on, then both unleashing and empowering teams that want to work on it is the way forward. The kind of leadership work that's called for here isn't "trigger puller" as much as "make them yearn for the immensity of the sea"-style inspiration. The small teams pull triggers.

I’ll throw my hat into the discussion here as well and agree with the confusion. I was active the first weekend, been a part of the discussion since, and not quite sure what we have today. As far as applications are concerned it’s been a bit confusing. I submitted one right away, then saw a community member share a ranking system, and now it’s part of the DAO race. 🤷‍♂️ Where this goes from here or at what point I’m supposed to be involved I’m not certain.

Okay trying to make Hyperscale more transparent & leverage the community.

Wrote up a brainstorming doc with some thoughts: problems, solutions, questions, & plan going forward.

Please help me brainstorm here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/11wVu2Iv4S-QdlsH-s67YmAjp32qmIHhhG-guCdkGce8/edit?usp=sharing

@here
cc: @DonaldBullers @Qworg @Party Doodle @connorg @xinyi @JayIRL @rx @aram @evann @Inklin @mhrnik @dtseto

embeds.title: Brainstorming - Governance & Community - Hyperscale
embeds.description: Here’s the legacy Notion doc: https://hyperscale.notion.site/Legacy-Notion-5ca332717d824f1da232f2c5d3b54737   Key community concerns > Tiered roles and lack of org transparency > Very centralized and no communication with the community > Not clear why roles are assigned or what they do > No clear...

messages.content: I know we’re all so in love with decentralized communities but they might not be the best format for productive decision making! Generally reaching consensus in big groups are hard! And the notion that majority is right is very likely the recipe for failure! For example, very few people would have voted for an idea like SpaceX or Tesla! Many big achievements in history have been made by small group of people who had a different view from majority! All I’m saying is we need to have a core and community! And I’m not sure where you want to draw the line on what can core folks do that community can’t but I think voting might be not be a good tool for a community to choose best idea! Maybe you want to give different weight to core vs community votes! Hopefully it’s not an excuse for not doing enough due diligence! I’m not sure how much a typical VC studies a company before investing in it!
Yeah but right now the core isn't transparent nor do we leverage the community
that I agree
We can have both. I held a fallacy that decentralized communities can't move fast
Which is what we're going to change

Decentralization is a choice, certainly, but no one is asking for consensus decisions. There are ways forward to bring the community into decision making that doesn't require pure democratic processes. Additional votes is certainly not the solution - we need to measure both _decisions_ AND _conviction_ around those decisions. Something like quadratic voting helps with that. I'd also address the idea that core makes better decisions than the rest of the community - that's also unproven.  In fact, one of the key goals of HS is to harness the wisdom of the crowd.
i think a commenting system could help, similar with pioneer
gives founders more insight, and gives voters more knowledge and can help ask the right questions

Going forward want to boil Hyperscale down to a forkable DAO.
- Direction
- Team that builds it fast
- Community of stakeholders that provide input

If someone disagrees with any of these components they can propose a change or fork.

"wisdom of the crowd" makes me worried! Because as Peter Theil says it can easily get converted to "madness of the crowd" ! Larry Ellison says the recipe for successful entrepreneur is finding holes in conventional wisdom! I agree that core can get into issues like group thinking, ignorance, but new and innovative things cannot stem from crowd because if it's known by crowd then it's not new! The idea that small groups submit ideas and win money is great but using the crowd to vote might undervalue the novelty of that small group. "Every great business is built around a secret that’s hidden from the outside. A great company is a conspiracy to change the world; when you share your secret, the recipient becomes a fellow conspirator.”
In crypto progress is made through forks

I deeply agree with this. A core team of founders create or fork Hyperscale. This team makes progress. Once there's shareholders their input is considered when choosing future direction.

Hey everyone, I'm very amazed by the speed of execution here! @kevalin Great commitment and work in just two weeks! I love the energy and discussion here! 

Please allow me to give an self-introduction. I'm product builder, patented inventor and startup founder, raised capital from VC, angels and accelerators for my last startup, now existing via IP sale. I lived in the SF Bay Area in 2017 & 2018, met Sam once in a YC event where he talked about UBI. He is such an impressive visionary! Born in China, spent most time in Boulder, Co before becoming an digital nomad this year, in Turkey now. More here(https://thelangmei.com/). I don't do status play, just trying providing my background so you understand where I'm coming from and the biases I have. And I'm very new to this whole DAO thing, never built a DAO or even a ICO 😭 in 2017. 

I tried to read through all chats and Notion docs posted from this Discord. Here're my initial thoughts:

1. Sam provided a vision for what Hyperscale is. He twittered about it. It's why everyone is here. Same for me. To build an organization, DAO or not DAO. We need a clear vision, mission and values among all members through our community brainstorming, discussion and debates. It's how a new startup/organization got formed. This is no discussion about the mission, what Hyperscale does, DAO is too generic, only covers some aspects of Hyperscale, not all. Clearly, there is no discussion about the core values to stick to Sam's vision, ex no-SV, no US centric. All I got is the Well-drafted Notion Doc pop up here and there in the chat. It's a great effort for sure, but not reflecting what the community wants Hyperscale to do. Vast majority of the people in this discord has no idea how to participate those early formation stage discussion at all, only being told on tactics level what to do, and prematurely determine many things without any consensus, ex bounty, leadership, DAO investment only. 

2. With my experience, to be effectively, we need to do things in stages, not shooting ourselves in too many directions at the same time without a clear roadmap. First we must define the mission, the core values we live by,  it along with Sam's brand attracts very talent and eager young people to join and form the (TEAM), then dive into the governance structure with flexibility for changes for at least first 1 year of the project (ex core vs. not core, how to become core) - like the DAO bylaw published for everyone, then we can get into the strategy level - the team structure (currently Notion doc shows only @kevalin on the core and it has a clear two layers and 3 departments, bwt, who decided that?), how to do investment, what do we invest, when to invest, the investment decision process, how to get deal-flows, how to give return back to the people/place we took money from, which assuming is decentralized and great individuals like Sam or entities like other DAOs. 

The typical VC has thesis to raise fund, not all VC are evil, they're actually very good at identifying startups/projects to fund, but due to the IRR pressure and some bad actors, now it gets some bad reputation. We should have a clear thesis, it allows us to build much better post-investment support and attract the right type of startups or DAOs to come to our website asking for funding. If we are not careful, we may end up attracting a lot of NFT visual arts projects or fun DAOs with no real world action plan, in stead, we probably better off by funding those web 3 developer tool & infrastructure startups, or even some UBI projects. It's up to this community to decided.

3. Currently on the Notion doc (Welcome to Hyperscale), it states (Hyperscale - A DAO that removes barriers to starting, funding, and building great DAOs). It's certainly not right to decide only investing in other DAOs, not startups or cool projects. I think it's clearly against Sam's points here(https://docs.google.com/document/d/1VnAykyT2mKcnPRv45rpAVVaVB6ZljwFUGh7MPxMYnvo/edit?usp=sharing). His investment terms/questions (Only for seed or also pre-seed? And fair economic terms?) clearly focus on startup investment, not other type of IDO, IEO or ICO financing terms in the crypto worlds. Personally, I'd love to see the crypto vehicles are being used by our DAOs to invest directly and quickly into meaningful, self-sustainable projects, startups or DAOs, not just another hyped new coins. 

4. On early stage "startup" building communication, it's super important to have brainstorming sessions, not via text, but meetings,  super important to form bonds, and build trusts and understanding. Just texting over Discord is not going to achieve that. It will just make the center-figure work way more than the rest, and slow down the information flows. I think before locking the mission statement of Hyperscale, bylaw as mentioned above, it at least needs few rounds of public community video calls, allowing as many people to join as possible, at the same time, having the Notion doc to record stuff (it's super impressive to see how well this is being implemented already). 

5. As a founder, I personally know and feel that point, it's easy to just point something wrong, but so much harder to spend the time to build and make changes. Since I'm not startup founder now, happy to contribute at least 10-20 hours per week into Hyperscale early stage building, not expecting any financial return in any way, but great learning for me on how to build a DAO and get into the web 3 if I'm being allowed into this project. (P.S. many people probably feels the same, not sure how to contribute this, but get excited by Sam's tweet. To get start, I can host Zoom sessions every Thursday and Sunday  11 am EST or any morning time to meet all the early community members. 

Sorry for any typos 😂 English is not my strong skill

For me there are 2 major challenges in the vision for Hyperscale for us to address. 

One is governance / how do we organise the community in order to get stuff done? The other is tokenomics v’s US securities law.

Tokenomics can come later but we need to solve governance now. Maybe that’s a charter or a constitution or a thesis or an operating manual, but some kind of founding document that describes how we organise. Including how new people can get involved.

Sama has said “what” Hyperscale’s mission is, but we need to say “how” we will organise a pool of people to achieve it.

Quick notes:
For a community/execution model what do we want to optimise for?
• build speed?
• community growth?
• community resilience?
• financial efficiency?
• core principles?
• other things?

Also… green papers and steelman edits are the way to progress here. It’s very easy to disagree with something, it’s much harder to propose a functional solution.

How to vote this project

Hi @rx 

Here is some constructive criticism:

So when I first joined this community. You sent me a private message with "Hi", when I asked you if you are part of Hyperscale, you said yes and responded with something like "They gave me the role of researcher". Then you sent a dozen links to some other projects and server invites. And that is called being vague and spammy. 

I understand that you mean well, and are very enthusiastic. But sending a lot of links without any reason is considered spammy and unsafe behaviour - what if if I click the links, they hijack my system via zero day vulns?

So in short: 

Sending unsolicited content and links, vague content, makes you appear spammy and untrustworthy. Also it annoys people and wastes time. You will also find that people may block you that way.

I hope you take this in good spirits and continue to do great contributions without the links and personal messages.
Hi

@lang thanks for posting this. I have offered lighter comments on this same topic. This is what the HS community needs to hear and make an effort to align. This project is moving way too fast with no strategic plan or mission and vision. 

I feel I have something significant to offer HS if I was a core member based on the research and work I've been doing over many years generally in strategy management and specifically in complex problem-solving in open, loosely connected networks. 

Even though I jumped in within two weeks of this project kicking off with Sam's tweet I have struggled to keep up with the convo and efforts. I spend all my time reading  through these channels to catch up but never feel I get there. I seem to always miss the conversations I can add value by a day or two. 

I've reached out to the core team to get some visibility so I can share what I'm working on to see if it can add value. Ironically, I don't know if my project is aligned because, as you correctly point out, there is no documented vision or strategy for HS. And double irony, what I have designed and build is a project that addresses this issue and more which plagues almost all open, loosely connected networks trying to accomplish something.  Frustratingly, my outreaches have been dismissed and I've been politely ask to move on from trying to participate in the design and development channels.

I hope this group takes your advice. At this infancy stage, things are understandably messy and no one is at fault. This is hard work and there will be trade-offs in all choices. Lets hope the people who can add value are found so we don't experience in the community what we are already saw happen with the first race.

messages.content: @JayIRL Pardon my ignorance, can you explain in layman's terms "proposals have a quorum requirement of 1% and require a minimum approval of 51% to pass" why was 1% and 51% chosen in particular why not for example anyone can create a proposal, request to update etc but require 3 votes to be listed and maybe anywhere from 51%-75% votes or whatever is considered a clear majority to pass. How would this look in numbers? What do you suggest with regard to time periods per proposal creation, changes, updates that people can vote for in governance.

Quorum requirement so that the processes doesnt get spammed.
51% to pass as a simple majority structure to begin with. 
If the community wishes to change those in teh future they 100% can , this is just to get a simple implementation on the table to begin with, the longer we take to debate over nuances without fundamentals in place the greater our risk to fail is in my opinion.
And to be clear, this is just a proposal, I have no formal role above anyone else! If someone wants to write a counterproposal they 100% can and we choose etc. Im just trying to move things along.

Hey yes I have seen in multiple channels now, as I said in the other thread, I think you can make a proposal after we have the fundamentals in place here to adopt (or not) such a solution.

Yes, I'm planning on following your advice and waiting for the vote to take place and then reaching out. It would be great to start with a meeting of interested participants and get feedback from that on whether I write a proposal, apply for a race to get funding or some other option brought up.

I wish I could jump in with some input on the proposal and to vote but I'll be away for the holiday weekend.

Sounds good everything. An idea that comes to mind. A proposal is submitted. Stays on a public list for 24 hours locked and with a new icon. The 24 hours time buffer is so that people can become aware of the proposal, time for revocation and prevention of duplicate / similar proposals and or proposal spam. After 24 hours elapse, it becomes unlocked and people can vote for inclusion or consideration for again 24 hours, if it has min number of 3 votes or whatever criteria, it moves to another list for main stream voting where people can cast votes for upto 1 week for that proposal else it would be archived and marked as zero traction. In mainstream 1 week voting, if it has passed, it would move to a implementation list where its status would be like initiated, ongoing, completed, live or whatever is applicable to the proposal. If it failed, it would be archived and marked as some traction, not passed. Transparent and informative.
Yup I like the concept, lets see where we go with the timeframes but the concept I like, feeds well into the phases

@JayIRL and everyone that contributed. Nice work. 

2 things: 

(1) How do we think about the tax implications (at least in the US) of this governance system for token holders?

(2) How might one estimate the practical burden or likelihood of meeting various quorum requirements and voting thresholds without an understanding of how tokens will be distributed initially?

So for 1) Im still very unclear on the actual legal structure of the vehicle or vehicles as we have not heard from Sama since Day 2 or so when we were told he was getting legal advice.
So for the moment I am working on the assumption that we are operating with a governance token, which at least for the moment may not be linked to the investment token, that is a total assumption on my part.
On the thresholds vs distribution strategy yes, I suspect that we will modify them once we have a tokenomics and distribution stategy hence keeping them simple and uncomplex, basically you need some minimial support and simple majority voting to begin with.

The proposal above with the exception of executable proposals is actually designed to even be workable without tokens on a pure membership voting structure (Hence tending to Snapshop over Sybil at this stage)

That way it would be easy to match folks to tasks and generate more community participation. Like a switchboard.
That should definitely be part of #product-design

All good thoughts on how to improve contribution mechanisms. There is an interesting process developed out of the Agile Strategy Lab at Purdue called Strategic Doing. A part of the process allows for people to list resources/skills at their personal disposal and through recombination with resources others offer come up with possible pathway projects that can be voted on to move forward on achieve an outcome where the path is not defined. 

Not pushing this for us, just riffing on the topic. Digitizing this process is one of the interesting things I have on the roadmap for my project.

To decentralize decicionmaking about which contributions are valueable and which are not: 

You should look into available human oracle voting systems. 

1. Fork one and populate it yourself by hand-picking a crowd of contributors of which you think they are authentic and have valuable ideas. 

2. Give them anonymous accounts in the voting system. Voters accounts should not be known identities to each other during the voting session, so collusion in decicionmaking is harder. 

3. chose lottocratically (!) a small subset of that oracle population, no need for everyone to vote everytime. Give that committee your questions to decide about, for example: "Certify a fact, is task XY finished? YES/NO" or an estimation like "How much should the contributor be paid on a scala of 1 to 10'  

4. Lottocratically chosen oracle committees have to pay a small voting fee (few dollar worth) to be allowed to participate in the secret voting.  Votes are only published when voting epoch ends  Voting fee turns into reward for those voting in majority. 

5. Restart the DAO-Race and make it a tournament, where random lottocratic oracle committees chose between three projects, the winner goes into next voting round, until only one is left. Oracles are incentified to do research and vote honestly, because they have to pay a small voting fee and only the majority vote earns rewards. So Random voting comes with risk of financial losses.

6. Test out to give more complex decicions to human oracles, eventually even considering lottocratic governance. 
You could secure it with something like quadratic courts. Each time a small committee decides in a way that doesnt seem legit to you, you can call in a bigger committee to challenge decicion of smaller committees. Worst case whole network is asked for legitimation. (But it doesnt make sense to ask whole network every time on every decicion, nor should everyone have a vote everytime, this is only the last resort)

Is the assumption that this functionality is created from scratch? There are a lot of projects out there that have done some amazing work building DAO tooling around fair voting. I don't see the logic in building this from scratch as it is not a differentiator for HS. 

I'd also point out something that doesn't make sense to me with Lottocratical voting in the context of funding races (I have not researched this voting type, btw). Financially penalizing voters who did not select the winning vote doesn't make sense when selecting a winner from what might be many worthy candidates. The vote is really saying what project, at this point in time, garners the most votes. A loosing project may very well gather the most votes at another point in time. Is Lottocracy best used when making a permanent decision around a set of mutually exclusive options?

Regarding small voting fee: as soon as there is something to earn with votings, people would probably start to vote randomly, just to become eligable for some future airdrop or stuff like that. But you want them rather to think about projects and really dive into whitepapers and pitches, otherwise their vote would be worthless to the dao-race.  So you could airdrop eligable voters a tradable hyper-token just enough to cover the gas fee and the voting fee. But to earn with their vote they would need to do research and come to a majority conclusion (therefore also secret votes to avoid collusion)

Regarding Lottocracy: this helps uncover crowd wisdom too, because it is more resistant against collusion, elites and inner circles. So it helps to avoid too much centralisation. Also it is more effective than giving everyone a vote. You wouldnt want to vote all the time.

.
Yes, would needed to be build mostly from the scratch. 

It depends what is important to the people behind this DAO and what they assume fair voting. 

If it is only about coin-voting, where wealthier people have more vote, than you are right, no need to reinvent the wheel , such DAO-Tools indeed allready exist. 

But i interpreted the idea of the first incarnation of the DAO-race that way, that this project is trying to uncover some crowd-wisdom from strangers. 

In that case Coin-voting (1$, 1vote) is just not good enough. In my opinion there is no wisdom in money but in people.
Sorry if it sounds too complicated, but actually it isnt. It is just a different paradigm. One human, one vote - instead of the usual one $ , one vote .
Thanks for the nuance. It helps. Now you got me curious so I'll have to keep digging deeper down the rabbit hole. I'm never getting out 😉

Lottocracy is very interesting @Ubiubi2018 ! Are there worked examples or a paper to refer to? 

Quadratic courts is awesome - that's how Morningstar Farms break deadlocks.
There was some work done decades ago
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3797
But i am not aware of similar initiatives on blockchain yet
You would likely just want to use a few bytes of the hash of some chains blocks, starting at a certain time. And than use it to select lottocratic delegates from your population

I wrote a proposal last autumn to govern a idena community multisig wallet with lottocracy and oracles. I hope we are going to try it out in a few weeks, community did vote for it. https://ubiubi2018.medium.com/proposal-for-governance-mechanism-for-idena-community-wallet-1d3f42819a50

But for sure such mechanism can be used by anyone. You just need ways that hinder people to game it. 

I think hyperscale could build something like that pretty fast on its own. Would be interesting. If just 'population' of eligable voters is elected wisely...

One human one vote is best but there is no Satoshi to invent a sibyl resistant electronic voting without KYC. It would be hard to tell who is a person and who is a bot without collecting SSNs, phone numbers, Driver licences etc. There are services working on that like Bright ID but still early days.

Have you checked Idena project? Yeah, it is not ideal, but seems pretty decent. Here are some basic ideas behind its consensus mechanism and AI-resistant tests which are made by humans for humans: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=minIUNYRv30
